questions.text: A patient presents to you with clubbing of fingers; hyperhidrosis; and thick, furrowed, and redundant skin on his forehead, cheeks, and chin. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pachydermoperiostosis:

A syndrome that combines hypertrophic osteoarthropathy and acromegalic features.

Patients with this disorder have cylindrical thickening of the limbs due to periostosis and skin changes.

The hereditary form of pachydermoperiostosis may be inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with incomplete penetrance and is most severe in males. Its onset usually occurs in the late teens.

The acquired form is not associated with a family history of the disorder, usually occurs in older men, and is associated with coexisting chronic cardiopulmonary or gastrointestinal neoplasm or infection.

  • Skin changes:
    • Marked thickening and oiliness of the skin of the hands, forearms, and legs;
    • Accentuation of facial folds
    • Hyperhidrosis of the hands and feet
    • Reduplication and furrowing of skin over the scalp (called cutis verticis gyrata, or "bulldog scalp").

There may also be macroglossia.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis of a patient reveals a pH of 7.55, pCO2- 54 mmHg, and HCO3- 40 mEq/L. What is the underlying disorder?

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
The underlying disorder in this patient is metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.55 indicates alkalosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 40 mEq/L, which in the presence of a high pH indicates metabolic alkalosis.

Step 3: pCO2 is 54 mmHg indicating respiratory acidosis. The increase in pCO2 along with the increase in pH suggests that this is a compensatory response.

Step 4: Assessing the compensatory response:

On average, the pCO2 rises 0.75 mmHg for every 1.0 mEq/L increment in the plasma HCO3-

In the above scenario, the plasma HCO3- concentration is increased to 40 mEq/L (The average normal value is considered as 24 mEq/L)

Thus, the HCO3- elevation is 40 – 24 = 16 mEq/L

Therefore, pCO2 elevation should be 0.75 × 16 =  12 mmHg

Now, considering that the average value of normal pCO2 is 40 mmHg, the estimated pCO2 measured should be 40 + 12= 52 mmHg.

As pCO2 is higher than the expected estimate, it is a case of metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of metabolic alkalosis?
questions.solution:
Mineralocorticoid deficiency does not cause metabolic alkalosis. Its excess causes metabolic alkalosis.

Causes of metabolic alkalosis:

Loss of hydrogen:

  • Gastrointestinal loss
    • Removal of gastric secretions - vomiting or nasogastric suction
    • Chloride-losing diarrhea
    • Gastrocolic fistula
    • Villous adenoma
    • Antacid therapy, particularly if combined with cation exchange resin
  • Renal loss
    • Loop or thiazide diuretics
    • Mineralocorticoid excess (primary aldosteronism, Cushing's, steroids, licorice)
    • Posthypercapnic states
    • Hypercalcemia, including milk-alkali syndrome
  • H+ movement into cells
    • Hypokalemia

Exogenous Alkali:

  • Administration of NaHCO3, sodium citrate/gluconate/acetate/antacids
  • Massive blood transfusion
  • Antacids- Milk alkali syndrome

Contraction alkalosis (loss of ECF volume):

  • Loop or thiazide-type diuretics
  • Sweat losses in cystic fibrosis
  • Gastric losses in achlorhydria

Miscellaneous:

  • Bartter's syndrome
  • Gitelman's syndrome

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with the lesions shown in the image. She also says that she has difficulty climbing the stairs and raising her arms above her head. The eyelids appear red in color. The probable diagnosis is _____.
questions.solution:
This image shows Gottron's papules, indicating a probable diagnosis of dermatomyositis, which is pathognomonic for this condition.

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations.

The classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Gottron’s papules - erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles
  • Heliotrope rash - erythematous discolouration of eyelids with periorbital edema
  • Shawl sign, which is macular erythema of the upper chest and back
  • V sign- rash on the sun-exposed anterior neck and chest
  • Nail bed telangiectasia
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Flagellate erythema
  • Mechanic’s hands- non‐inflammatory hyperkeratosis occurring on the hands or feet, usually over the radial surfaces of the fingers and the outer border of the feet
  • Deposition of calcium in the tissues

The image below shows shawl sign. 

The below image shows V sign

Below image shows linear extensor erythema

questions.text: Based on your observation of the foot of the patient shown below, what is the most likely diagnosis and its inheritance pattern?
questions.solution:
The given image shows periungual fibroma seen in tuberous sclerosis. Periungual fibromas are benign tumors that are composed of connective tissue and typically appear in the second decade of life or later.

Tuberous sclerosis is an inherited neurocutaneous disorder. It is inherited in autosomal dominant pattern.

The clinical features include:

  • Ash-leaf macules - hypopigmented macules -
  • Facial angiofibroma
  • Shagreen patches mostly over the lower back
  • Periungual fibromas

The image below shows an ash leaf macule.

The image below shows a Shagreen patch.

questions.text: A first-year pathology resident prepares the following smear from a patient's blood sample. Which of the following is it suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The small, dense RBCs with absent central pallor seen in the given peripheral smear are called spherocytes. They appear due to decreased membrane surface area and are seen in the following conditions:

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Clostridial sepsis
  • Snake bites

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a BMI of 41 kg/m2 is being evaluated for bariatric surgery. Which of the following procedures does not reduce the surface area for iron absorption?
questions.solution:
Iron absorption takes place in the duodenum. In sleeve gastrectomy, a portion of the stomach is resected but the duodenum remains intact. Hence, the surface area of iron absorption is not affected.

Dietary iron is efficiently absorbed in its heme form. Non-heme iron is less efficiently absorbed mainly because of interference by phosphates, tannins, oxalates, and other food constituents. Acidic pH enhances iron absorption by promoting the conversion of ferric to ferrous iron by the enzyme ferrireductase. 

 

The following are malabsorptive procedures that reduce the duodenal surface area and hence, reduce iron absorption:

  • Biliopancreatic diversion
  • Roux-en-Y gastric bypass
  • Duodenal switch

questions.text: Which of the following would not be seen in patients with sideroblastic anemia?
questions.solution:
High serum iron levels are seen in patients with sideroblastic anemia.

Sideroblastic anemia presents with the following features:

  • Serum iron level - high/normal
  • Transferrin saturation - high
  • Serum ferritin levels - high
  • TIBC - low/normal
  • Peripheral smear - dimorphic population (both microcytes and macrocytes).
  • Bone marrow study - marked erythroid hyperplasia.

The iron profile of sideroblastic anemia is opposite to that of iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about polycythemia vera is true?

choices.text: Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis
Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation
It is protective against H.pylori infection
Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality

questions.solution:
Generalized pruritus seen in polycythemia vera (PV) is a consequence of the activation of mast cells by JAK 2 mutation.

Other options:

Option A: The risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with erythrocytosis, not the degree of thrombocytosis.

Option C: In polycythemia vera, there is an increased risk of H.pylori infection.

Option D: Thrombosis is the major cause of mortality in polycythemia vera. The incidence of acute leukemia in patients not exposed to chemotherapy or radiation therapy is low.

PV is a clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder in which red cells, granulocytes & platelets accumulate in the absence of a physiological stimulus. The most common mutation seen in PV is the JAK2 mutation.

Clinical features of polycythemia vera are:

  • Thrombosis is the most common manifestation and is the major cause of mortality. Uncontrolled erythrocytosis causes increased viscosity of the blood causing thrombosis of the vessels. Patients may present with stroke, transient ischemic attacks, myocardial infarction, and Budd-Chiari syndrome.
  • Aquagenic pruritis is generalized itching following a warm bath or a shower due to increased mast cells and histamine.
  • Erythromelalgia is erythema and pain in the fingers, hands, and feet due to increased platelet stickiness.
  • Splenomegaly due to increased destruction of RBCs in the spleen
  • Gout is due to the excessive proliferation of the marrow cells leading to elevated uric acid levels.

questions.text:
During a routine health checkup, the following lab reports were obtained for a young male patient. What will be your next step in the evaluation?

Hb: 17 g/dl

TLC: 5500 /μL

Platelets: 1,69,000 /μL
questions.solution:
This patient has increased Hb and normal WBCs and platelets. The next step is to measure RBC mass to evaluate for polycythemia.

A person has to be evaluated for polycythemia if there is:

  • Increased hemoglobin: >16.5 g/dL in men or >16.0 g/dL in women, (or)
  • Increased hematocrit: >49 percent in men or >48 percent in women

This condition is due to either a true increase in the number of RBCs (absolute polycythemia) or an apparent increase due to a decrease in the plasma volume (relative polycythemia). Both of these conditions can be differentiated by measuring RBC mass (amount of total blood volume that is occupied by RBCs).

In patients with absolute polycythemia, erythropoietin (EPO) levels must be measured.

  • Primary polycythemia - low or normal EPO levels
  • Secondary polycythemia - elevated EPO levels

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text: Two weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection, a 5-year-old presents with ecchymosis and petechiae all over the body. Abdominal examination revealed no hepatosplenomegaly. The platelet count is 15,000/µL and the coagulation profile is normal. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Bone marrow biopsy shows increased megakaryocytes
Bleeding into the joints is a common manifestation
The condition resolves spontaneously in 80% patients

questions.solution:
This scenario is suggestive of acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura. Bleeding into the joints is seen in coagulation disorders and is not a manifestation of this condition.

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura or idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)  is an acquired disorder in which there is an immune-mediated destruction of platelets. It can be acute or chronic.

Acute ITP is common in children and is usually preceded by viral infection. It presents with mucocutaneous bleeding (epistaxis, petechiae, ecchymosis). Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, fever and jaundice are absent. The following laboratory features are seen:

  • Thrombocytopenia (commonly <20,000 / μL)
  • Bleeding time - prolonged
  • PT/aPTT/INR - normal
  • Bone marrow - normal/increased megakaryocytes
  • Peripheral smear - normal

This condition resolves spontaneously in 80% of the cases. Treatment is as follows:

  • Platelet count < 30,000 with risk factors for bleeding (antiplatelet drugs/anticoagulants or concomitant bleeding disorders): Oral glucocorticoids or IVIG 
  • Severe bleeding symptoms: IV methylprednisolone ± IVIG 
  • Life-threatening bleeding (like intracranial hemorrhage): platelet transfusion + IV methylprednisolone + IVIG

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man is found to have the following findings on a routine CBC. A subsequent peripheral smear is performed as shown below. A bone marrow aspiration study is planned for this patient. All of the following are likely to be seen on bone marrow except:

Hemoglobin - 8.4 g/dL

WBC count - 1,65,000/cu.mm

Platelet count - 6,10,000/cu.mm
questions.solution:
The image shows a left-shift with a predominance of segmented neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes that is suggestive of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). Marrow blasts are usually < 5% in the majority of CML patients.

In CML, the following bone marrow findings are noted:

  • Markedly hypercellularity - due to increased granulocytic precursors
    • Myeloid: erythroid ratio (M/E ratio) is significantly increased 
    • Megakaryocytes - normal or increased
    • Erythroid precursors - usually decreased
  • Sea blue histiocytes - macrophages with abundant wrinkled, green-blue cytoplasm.
  • Bone marrow fibrosis may occur due to the deposition of reticulin.
  • Pseudo-Gaucher cells - macrophages with wrinkled tissue paper appearance, as shown below. Due to the increased turnover of the cells, there is an increased accumulation of glucocerebroside within the macrophages.

questions.text: Which lead does the given ECG tracing represent in a normal ECG?
questions.solution:
As all the waves (P, QRS, T) are negative in the given ECG, it should be lead aVR. All the depolarisations waves (P, QRS, T) move away from lead aVR in the normal sinus.

Depolarisation wave moving towards the positive pole of the lead (or active electrode) produces a positive deflection in the ECG and depolarization moving away from the positive pole of the lead produces a negative deflection in the ECG.

The lead aVR provides information from the right upper side of the heart.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency room complaining his heart is pounding and that he is going to die. The emergency physician orders an ECG. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows ST elevation in leads V1-V4 which is suggestive of acute anteroseptal myocardial infarction (MI). ST depression in the leads III and aVF signifies an old inferior wall infarction.

questions.solution: The given image is of mitral stenosis showing fish mouth or buttonhole appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Beck’s triad?
questions.solution:
Pulsus paradoxus is not part of Beck’s triad. Pulsus paradoxus is seen in cardiac tamponade. However, it is not a part of Beck's triad.

Beck’s triad is seen in cardiac tamponade and it includes: 

  • Hypotension
  • Soft or absent heart sounds
  • Jugular venous distension

Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space significant enough to cause an obstruction to the inflow of blood to the ventricles. This reduces cardiac output and arterial pressure causing hypotension. 

This also causes a greater than the normal reduction in the systolic arterial blood pressure producing pulsus paradoxus. Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration.

Other causes of pulsus paradoxus include:

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Severe obstructive lung disease
  • Hemorrhagic shock

The echocardiography clip below shows the swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac tamponade.

questions.text:
An RTA victim is brought with breathing difficulty. On examination, the following is noted. Which of the following JVP findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
  • BP- 80/58mmHg
  • Pulse- feeble
  • JVP- elevated
  • Heart sounds- muffled

choices.text: Absent x and prominent y descent
Prominent x and absent y descent

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated JVP (Beck's triad) suggest a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. The JVP finding most likely to be seen is prominent x descent and absent y descent.

 

Note: JVP in constrictive pericarditis is characterized by prominent x and y descents.

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac biomarkers is the earliest to rise after acute myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Myoglobin is the earliest to rise in acute MI followed by troponin, CK-MB and then LDH.

Serum myoglobin and heart-type fatty acid-binding protein are smaller molecules that diffuse through interstitial ﬂuids more rapidly after cell death than the larger CK and troponin molecules. They become abnormal as early as 30 minutes after myocardial injury. Neither molecule is specific to myocardial tissue. Myoglobin levels are not tested in routine practice.

questions.text: A concerned wife brought her 43-year-old husband to the clinic after an episode of light-headedness and palpitations. An ECG was taken. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms and ECG findings suggestive of Mobitz type I or Wenckebach block.

In the given ECG PR segment progressively increases in each successive cycle, until a P wave of the series fails to produce a QRS complex (dropped QRS). In this example, for every 5 'P' waves, there are only 4 'QRS' complexes; hence, this is a 5:4 Wenckebach block.

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: Urinary antigen detection test is recommended for diagnosing patients with?
questions.solution:
A urinary antigen detection test is recommended for the diagnosis of Legionella pneumonia. The sensitivity (70%) and specificity (99%) of the test are high.

The test can detect antigen even after the initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy. Urinary antigen detection test can also be used for Streptococcus pneumonia but is not used due to the availability of better alternatives.

Other investigations for Legionella:

  • DFA (direct fluorescent antibody)- is highly specific but not sensitive
  • Culture- Gold standard, BCYE media is used
  • DNA detection with PCR

Treatment: Drugs of choice are azithromycin and respiratory fluoroquinolones (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin).

questions.text:
A 55-year-old smoker presents with high-grade fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, and confusion. Gram-staining of the sputum revealed neutrophilia with no organisms. Chest x-ray showed bilateral multilobar infiltrates. Lab values are given below. Which pathogenic agent is suspected?
Parameters Values
ALT 63 IU/L
AST 54 IU/L
Bilirubin 0.8 mg/dl
S. Na 129 mEq/l
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by legionella. 

Clinical features of Legionnaire's disease:

  • High-grade-fever( >104 F)
  • Cough with scanty sputum
  • Extrapulmonary manifestations involve
    • gastrointestinal- diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting
    • neurological- most common-confusion, headache, encephalopathy
  • Relative bradycardia
  • Occurrence of illness in an environment in which water supply is at risk of contamination
  • Failure to respond to beta-lactams and aminoglycoside antibiotics

Investigations:

  • On gram-staining of the sputum, numerous neutrophils with no organisms
  • Hyponatremia
  • Elevated liver enzymes

questions.text: The most common type of interstitial lung disease (ILD)  is_____
questions.solution:
Idiopathic interstitial pneumonia (IIP) is the most common type of ILD.

The most common subtype of IIP is idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis also known as usual interstitial pneumonia. 

Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) is the typical pathological finding in patients with suspected idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).

Patients with UIP typically present in their sixth and seventh decades.

Men are affected more commonly than women.

High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) demonstrates a characteristic pattern of peripheral (subpleural), bibasilar reticular opacities associated with architectural distortion, including honeycomb changes and traction bronchiectasis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital with a fever and cough. She has a history of repeated chest infections for several years and coughs up yellow-green purulent sputum with some streaky hemoptysis. What could be the underlying condition based on the CT given below?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the CT showing signet ring sign is suggestive of bronchiectasis which can be due to cystic fibrosis.

A history of repeated chest infections is an indication of cystic fibrosis and a major risk factor for the development of bronchiectasis.

questions.text: Which of the following would be elevated in patients with chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is associated with elevated levels of fibrinogen. 

CKD is a pro-inflammatory state characterized by altered levels of acute-phase reactants (APR) 

  • Elevated levels of positive APR like CRP and fibrinogen (associated with high ESR).
  • Reduced levels of negative APR like albumin and fetuin.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with CKD has been on dialysis for 3 months. He now presents with intense body pains and muscle pain. He suffered from 2 fractures over the last 2 months.  On evaluation, he was found to have decreased PTH levels and normal calcium levels. He has been regularly taking oral vitamin D and calcium tablets. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario in a CKD patient is suggestive of adynamic bone disease.

In CKD, metabolic bone disorders (renal osteodystrophy) can be of three types:

Osteitis fibrosa cystica Osteomalacia Adynamic bone disease
High bone turnover

Low bone turnover

Low bone turnover
Renal calcium loss  Decreased calcitriol formation leads to low calcium

It is an iatrogenic condition

Increased intake of vitamin D or calcium-containing phosphate binders or dialysis.
High PTH occurs in response to low calcium (secondary hyperparathyroidism)

Low vitamin D leads to defective mineralization

Decreased calcium leads to a mild increase in PTH, which stimulates osteoblasts. Thus the bone volume is maintained.

High vitamin D  decreases PTH levels, which leads to decreased bone volume.

Mineralization is defective because of aluminium, which comes from dialysis.

Treatment:

Vitamin D + calcium

Treatment:

Vitamin D + calcium

Treatment:

Withdrawal of offending agent

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with chest pain that is radiating to his shoulder, shortness of breath, and diaphoresis. He is a known case of chronic kidney disease. Which of the following investigations is best for diagnosis?

choices.text: Troponin levels on admission and 1 hour later
Troponin and CK-MB levels at admission

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myocardial infarction (MI) in a patient with chronic kidney disease (CKD). A serial rise in cardiac troponin levels over 3-6 hours following presentation is needed to make a diagnosis. An interval of 1-hour is not considered sufficient. 

Minor chronic elevations in serum troponins are commonly observed in patients with CKD even in the absence of cardiovascular disease. Hence, a single elevated troponin value in such patients cannot be used to diagnose MI. 

CK-MB is far less sensitive and specific than troponins. Hence, it is not preferred.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about hemodialysis?​

choices.text: Dialyzers are made up of cellulose membranes
Bicarbonate is commonly used as a buffer
Glutaraldehyde  is used as a reprocessing agent
Urea is cleared more efficiently than creatinine

questions.solution:
In hemodialysis, the dialyzer is made up of biocompatible membranes derived from polysulfone. Cellulose is bio-incompatible and is no longer used.

Hemodialysis is based on the principle of solute diffusion using an artificial semi-permeable membrane. Smaller molecules (urea) diffuse faster and are cleared more efficiently than larger molecules (creatinine). There are three components to this system:

  • Dialyzer - a chamber that contains compartments for blood and dialysate solution, separated by a semipermeable membrane. 
  • Dialysate - a solution that helps in the removal of metabolic waste products. Bicarbonate is used as a buffer to correct acidosis in CKD patients.
  • Blood delivery system - consists of the vascular access and extracorporeal circuit.

The dialyzers used during a session of dialysis are reprocessed and reused for the next dialysis sessions. The reprocessors used for dialyzers are: 

  • Glutaraldehyde
  • Formaldehyde  
  • Peracetic acid-hydrogen peroxide

The following image depicts hemodialysis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding trigeminal neuralgia?

choices.text: The region of ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve is always spared
The pain usually last for a few hours
The condition is also known as tic douloureux
It is more common in men

questions.solution:
Tic douloureux is another term for trigeminal neuralgia.

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by frequent paroxysms of severe pain in the lips, gums, cheek, or chin. It is sometimes seen in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.

Middle-aged and elderly females are primarily affected. The pain usually lasts for a short time (seconds to minutes) but be may intense enough that the patient winces, hence the term 'tic'.

A characteristic feature is the presence of trigger zones, typically on the face, lips, or tongue. Patients usually report excruciating pain during activities such as washing the face or brushing the teeth. However, no signs of sensory loss can be demonstrated.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents with complaints of resting tremor in his right hand, which improves with movement. He also says that he has difficulty initiating movements and his wife says his movements have been slow. On examination, rigidity is observed to passive arm movement and shuffling gait with a stooped posture is noticed.  Which of the following statements is false regarding the pathology of this condition?

choices.text: Substantia nigra pars reticulata is unaffected by the disease process
Decreased striatal dopamine is seen in this condition
Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta
Lewy bodies which containing degenerated tau protein are seen

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Parkinson's disease and Lewy bodies seen in Parkinson's disease do not contain tau protein. They contain the protein α-synuclein.

Pathologic hallmarks of Parkinson's disease include:

  • Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc)
  • Reduced striatal dopamine
  • Intracytoplasmic proteinaceous inclusions called Lewy bodies, which contain the protein α-synuclein

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the casualty after she tripped over a stone. She has been having trouble sleeping and abdominal discomfort. Her daughter said that she has become forgetful and her movements are very slow. She is diagnosed with Parkinson's disease. Which of her symptoms will be relieved by treatment with levodopa?
questions.solution:
Levodopa is useful in alleviating the bradykinesia (slow movement) seen in Parkinson's disease.

Levodopa in Parkinson's disease

Levodopa benefits

Classic motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease:

  • Bradykinesia
  • Rigidity
  • Tremor

Levodopa does not benefit

Non-dopaminergic features:

  • Freezing
  • Falling
  • Sleep disorders
  • Dementia
  • Autonomic dysfunction (GI disturbances, orthostatic hypotension etc.)

questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with West syndrome?
questions.solution:
Café au lait is a neurocutaneous marker seen in neurofibromatosis, not a component of West syndrome. 

The triad of West syndrome is:

  • Infantile spasms (also called Salaam spells)
  • Developmental regression
  • Hypsarrhythmia (abnormal EEG)

West syndrome is treated with:

  • ACTH injections
  • Vigabatrin if associated with tuberous sclerosis

questions.text: Which of the following sensory deficits is severely affected in a patient with Guillain-Barre syndrome?
questions.solution:
Loss of proprioception is severe in Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS).

GBS affects the large sensory fibers, leading to attenuation or loss of deep tendon reflexes and loss of proprioception.

Cutaneous sensory deficits (e.g., loss of pain and temperature sensation) are usually relatively mild.

questions.text: A patient presents to your OPD with galactorrhea and amenorrhea. Apart from the determination of serum prolactin levels, which other investigation would you like to do?
questions.solution:
TSH should be measured along with the prolactin level to rule out hypothyroidism which can cause hyperprolactinemia.

Note: However, pregnancy (using qualitative HCG) should be ruled out in all women of the reproductive age group with amenorrhea.

questions.text: You have started a 40-year-old man on treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus and dyslipidemia. Which of the following is not an appropriate target for this patient?
questions.solution:
According to the ADA guidelines, a treatment goal of postprandial plasma glucose < 180 mg/dL must be followed in adults with diabetes.

In younger individuals or those with other cardiovascular risk factors, the target blood pressure is < 130/80 mm Hg. Although not a treatment goal, the ADA also recommends triglyceride levels be maintained at < 150 mg/dl.

Note: Saroglitazar is a more advanced drug that reduces blood sugar and lipid levels in diabetic patients. It acts on PPAR alpha and gamma receptors.

Related Pearl: Treatment Goals for Adults with Diabetes

Goal

< 7 %

80–130 mg/dL

Peak postprandial capillary plasma glucose

<180 mg/dL

< 140/80 mmHg

*Note that most diabetes associations recommend the target HbA1c must be individualized to the patient. A target of <7% is reasonable in most individuals.

+ Blood pressure: Harrison's 20th  edition,(based on ADA) recommends the target blood pressure goal of <140/90 mmHg for adults with diabetes. It further adds that for younger individuals the target blood pressure is <130/80 mmHg. But the "AHA/SPRINT TRIAL recommendations" recommend that the goal of blood pressure in patients with diabetes mellitus is less than 130/80 mmHg.

Dyslipidemia: Although not a treatment goal, ADA recommends to intensify lifestyle therapy and optimize glycemic control for patients with elevated triglyceride levels (≥150 mg/dL [1.7 mmol/L]) and/or low HDL cholesterol (<40 mg/dL for men, <50 mg/dL  for women). Treatment with statins would depend on the overall cardiovascular risk (ASCVD) rather than specific LDL/HDL cholesterol level.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy has been on treatment for type 1 diabetes mellitus since the age of 10 years. His physician decides to begin screening for diabetic nephropathy. Which of the following is not always a reliable indicator of this condition?
questions.solution:
Albumin of 30-300 mg/day refers to microalbuminuria. It can be unreliable in the diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy.

It is not required to diagnose nephropathy as it is very variable. Non-albuminuric diabetic nephropathy may occur in some patients and regression of albuminuria may be seen in type 1 diabetics.

Diabetic nephropathy can be diagnosed if the following are satisfied: 

  • Reduced GFR (< 60 mL/min/1.73 m2) with or without persistent albuminuria (> 30 mg/day or urine PCR > 30 mg/g)
  • Long duration of diabetes or established diabetic retinopathy
  • Other etiologies are ruled out

Long duration in type 1 diabetes refers to 5 years after diagnosis. On the other hand, patients with type 2 diabetes are exposed to hyperglycemia and prediabetes for a long time even before diagnosis. Hence, at the time of diagnosis, patients with type 2 diabetes are considered to have had the disorder for a duration sufficiently long to produce kidney disease.

However, a clinical diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy can be made in patients with established retinopathy, even if the duration of diabetes is short.

questions.text: In a patient with reduced cortisol and elevated ACTH, which of the following would not be part of your differential diagnoses?
questions.solution:
Elevated ACTH and reduced cortisol levels are seen in primary adrenal insufficiency. It is not a feature of MEN 4 syndrome.

The following syndromes are associated with primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome type 1
  • Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome type 2
  • Triple-A syndrome
  • Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome
  • Kearns-Sayre syndrome
  • IMAGe syndrome

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: What is the most common biochemical abnormality seen at presentation in patients with adrenal insufficiency?
questions.solution:
Hyponatremia is the most common biochemical abnormality seen at presentation in patients with adrenal insufficiency. It is observed in 80% of the patients at presentation.

Hyponatremia is caused by:

  • Mineralocorticoid deficiency
  • Diminished inhibition of ADH release by cortisol, resulting in mild SIADH during secondary adrenal insufficiency

Hyperkalemia is diagnosed in 40% of the patients during initial diagnosis.

questions.text: You can advise any of the following tests for screening of a patient suspected to be having Cushing's syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Determination of plasma ACTH levels is not advised as a screening test for a patient with Cushing's syndrome.

Plasma ACTH determination is done to distinguish between ACTH-dependent and independent causes. It is done after the screening or confirmation of Cushing's syndrome.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: The Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score cut off suggestive of significant mortality in alcoholic hepatitis is _____
questions.solution:
MELD score which is 21 or more is also associated with significant mortality in alcoholic hepatitis.

  • The presence of ascites, variceal hemorrhage, deep encephalopathy, or hepatorenal syndrome predicts a dismal prognosis.
  • The pathologic stage of the injury can be helpful in predicting prognosis

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: An infant presented with yellow discolouration of the skin, poor feeding, and seizures. Investigations revealed total bilirubin- 40 mg/dL and unconjugated bilirubin- 34 mg/dL. Phenobarbitone was administered while blood was being arranged for an exchange transfusion. However, there was no improvement. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with poor feeding and seizures is indicative of kernicterus. This accompanied with unconjugated hyperbilrubinemia is highly suggestive of Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1.

No improvement in bilirubin levels following the administration of phenobarbital further supports the diagnosis. 

Crigler-Najjar syndrome is of two types with type 1 having absent/trace enzyme activity and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Hence, type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage. Type 2 may also lead to kernicterus occasionally. 

Kernicterus occurs because the unconjugated bilirubin is lipid-soluble and hence crosses the blood-brain barrier. 

Phenobarbital is an enzyme inducer. Its administration can be used to differentiate between type 1 and type 2 Crigler-Najjar.

  • Enzyme induction by phenobarbital leads to improved conjugation of bilirubin leading to a reduction in total bilirubin level in type 2 Crigler-Najjar syndrome.
  • No improvement is seen in type 1 as the enzyme activity is absent and therefore cannot be induced.

Inherited unconjugated hyperbilirubinemias (Autosomal Recessive) include:

 

Crigler-Najjar type  I

Crigler-Najjar type II

 Gilbert Syndrome
UDP-GT Activity  Absent Markedly reduced Reduced
Serum bilirubin 20 - 45 mg/dl <20 mg/dl Generally <3 mg/dl
Pheno-barbital effect on serum bilirubin No effect Reduction Reduction
Outcome Kernicterus Usually benign, kernicterus is rare  Benign
Prevalence Rare  Rare  Common

Note: Rotor syndrome causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

The normal serum bilirubin (between 1 and 1.5 mg/dL) present in serum represents a balance between input from the production of bilirubin and hepatic/biliary removal of the pigment.

Isolated elevation of the bilirubin:

  • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia- >15% conjugated bilirubin
  • Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia- <15% conjugated bilirubin

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis is now diagnosed with primary biliary cholangitis. Which of the following is false regarding her lab values?
questions.solution:
Anti-LKM 2 antibodies are not seen in primary biliary cholangitis. They are seen in drug-induced hepatitis.

The laboratory findings of primary biliary cholangitis include :

  • Liver function tests
    • Elevated ALP 
    • Elevated GGT and 5'- nucleotidase
    • Elevated ALT and AST
  • Serology - 
    • Antimitochondrial antibodies - positive in 95% of patients. These are mostly directed against the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex.
    • Antinuclear antibodies
  • Elevated HDL, LDL, and VLDL
  • Elevated serum IgM

Hyperbilirubinemia is seen once cirrhosis has developed.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male complains of dysphagia and regurgitation of food that has been eaten 3 days back. He has foul breath and a gurgling sound is heard on swallowing. 
The most likely diagnosis is _____
questions.solution:
The history is suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. If often presents with the following:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Gurgling sound on swallowing
  • Aspiration

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: Identify the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image depicts eosinophilic esophagitis.

The characteristic endoscopic esophageal findings are loss of vascular markings (edema), multiple oesophageal rings, longitudinally oriented furrows, and punctate exudate.

Etiologies of esophageal eosinophilia include GERD, drug hypersensitivity, connective tissue disorders, and hypereosinophilic syndrome infection.

Current evidence indicates that EoE is an immunologic disorder induced by antigen sensitization in susceptible individuals. Dietary factors play an important role in both pathogenesis and treatment of EoE. Aeroallergens may also contribute.

Histologic confirmation: 15 eosinophils per high power field

Update: Previously, a two-month trial with a proton-pump inhibitor showing persistence of esophageal eosinophilia on mucosal biopsy was required to establish a diagnosis of EoE. Currently, this is no longer a criterion.

questions.text: All the following are components of the Harmless acute pancreatitis score  except:
questions.solution:
Serum Calicum is NOT a part of Harmless acute pancreatitis score(HAPS).

HAPS predicts a non-severe course of pancreatitis with 98% accuracy.

It has the following components:

  • Absence of rebound abdominal tenderness/guarding
  • Normal hematocrit value
  • Normal serum creatinine level

Scoring Systems Used for Acute Pancreatitis

  • RANSON criteria
  • BISAP score (Bedside Index for Severity in Acute Pancreatitis)
  • HAPS (Harmless acute pancreatitis score)
  • Revised Atlanta classification

Related Pearl: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

  • Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes:
    • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL
    • Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15
    • Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
    • Age > 60 years
    • Pleural effusion
      One point is given for each. BISAP score ≥ 3 indicates severe pancreatitis.
  • Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS)
    If all the following are present then it is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need for ventilation:
    • Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding
    • Normal hematocrit
    • Normal serum creatinine

  • Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II)
    • A score of 8 or more is considered to be severe
    • Can be done at admission and repeated any time
    • Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age
  • Ranson’s score
  • Modified Glasgow criteria - 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered to be severe
  • Atlanta classification

questions.text: A software engineer presented with complaints of dryness and itching of eyes on staring at his laptop screen. On examination, parotid swelling was noted and the test shown below was positive. The serology of this patient is likely to be positive for which of the following antibodies?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of dry eyes, parotid swelling, and a positive Schirmer test is suggestive of Sjögren's syndrome. It is associated with anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B autoantibodies.

The presence of anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B indicate extra glandular involvement and poor prognosis.

Note: Anti-Ro and anti-La in SLE indicate a good prognosis, due to decreased risk of nephritis and vasculitis.

questions.text: A patient complains about difficulty doing chores due to morning stiffness of the joints. Investigations show elevated ESR, CRP, and positive Rheumatoid factor. Which of the following is not likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis, which is associated with hypoandrogenism. 

It is characterized by low levels of serum testosterone, LH, and DHEA.

The conditions associated with rheumatoid arthritis are:

  • Cardiovascular disease, congestive heart failure
  • Osteoporosis - hip fractures are more likely to occur
  • Ocular - keratoconjunctivitis sicca, episcleritis, scleritis, keratitis
  • Secondary Sjogren's syndrome
  • Hypoandrogenism in men and postmenopausal women

questions.text: Anti centromere antibody is characteristic of _____
questions.solution:
Anti-centromere antibody is the characteristic autoantibody seen in Limited Cutaneous Systemic sclerosis.

Anti-topoisomerase I and anti RNA polymerase III are seen in Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic sclerosis.
